item.title: Bash string comparison
item.description:
String comparison is easy in Bash. We need to put the expression inside a [[ ]]. Following illustrates a Bash session with string comparison. For comparing two strings both = and == works!

System Message: ERROR/3 (/home/jestinjoy/pelican/content/bash_str_comp.rst, line 11)

Content block expected for the "code-block" directive; none found.

.. code-block:: bash
        jestinjoy@debian:~$ string=new
        jestinjoy@debian:~$ [[ $string = new ]]
        jestinjoy@debian:~$ echo $?
        0
        jestinjoy@debian:~$ [[ $string == new ]]
        jestinjoy@debian:~$ echo $?
        0
        jestinjoy@debian:~$ [[ $string == old ]]
        jestinjoy@debian:~$ echo $?
        1
        jestinjoy@debian:~$ [[ $string = old ]]
        jestinjoy@debian:~$ echo $?
        1

echo $? prints the exit status of the previously typed command. The return value is 0 if the string matches and 1 otherwise.

We can also use patterns inside [[ ]].
item.dc:creator: Jestin Joy

item.title: Julia tested against Python using sorting
item.description:
With Wired terming it is as "a new language they hope will be suited to practically any task. ", thought of giving it a try. One major feature emphasized about Julia was its speed. So run sorting on 1,00,000 numbers using both Julia and Python. What I have done is

  1. Run inbuilt sorting methods of Julia and Python on large set of numbers
  2. Run custom sorting method (insertion sort based on programming pearls book) using Julia and Python

As expected Julia completed sorting faster than Python for inbuilt and custom versions.

I have used matplotlib to plot the result.

Using built-in sort method.

Using custom sort method.
item.dc:creator: Jestin Joy
